comments.body: A namespace for this is a little heavyweight; what about just doing an `export type` at the top level?

I'd like to go with the namespace approach, because it's not breaking existing codebases. Currently you can use multiple ways of importing the `shallowequal`, e.g.

`import shallowequal from 'shallowequal`
`import eq from 'shallowequal'`

If you export the type on top level, you break this, because you have to use

`import { shallowEqual } from 'shallowequal'`

or

`import { shallowEqual, Comparer } from 'shallowequal'`

So I think it's a good tradeoff to have a namespace which might not be necessary instead of breaking existing codebases.
To me, it's kinda more idiomatic to not return anything instead of an `undefined` value. Why did you change this, was there a technical reason or purely aethetical?

It's legal to mix default and non-default imports, so you should be able to `import eq, { Comparer } from 'shallowequal';` meaning it'll be backwards-compatible.

In any case, I don't mind either way aesthetically speaking, but I do know that namespace-merging is sometimes considered an anti-pattern, which is why I raised it.

I'm okay with these changes as-is; I'll defer to @BendingBender to approve since they've got other comments.

Sorry, maybe I misunderstand you, but I've tested what you said and it seems not to be correct.

Following code was run with `"strictNullChecks": "true"`:
```typescript
const u: undefined = null; // error
const n: null = undefined; // error
const v: void = null; // error
const v1: void = undefined; // ok
const v2: void = void 0; // ok

function a(): void {
  return undefined; // ok
}

function b(): undefined {} // error

function c(): undefined {
    return null; // error
}
```

The same code with `"strictNullChecks": "false"`:
```typescript
const u: undefined = null; // ok
const n: null = undefined; // ok
const v: void = null; // ok
const v1: void = undefined; // ok
const v2: void = void 0; // ok

function a(): void {
  return undefined; // ok
}

function b(): undefined {} // error

function c(): undefined {
    return null; // ok
}
```

So actually, in non-`strictNullChecks` mode the only difference between `void` and `undefined` is that the former doesn't require a return value, while the latter requires an explicit return of `undefined`.

It doesn't protect you from incorrectly returning `null` in non-`strictNullChecks` mode.

> I'd like to go with the namespace approach, because it's not breaking existing codebases. Currently you can use multiple ways of importing the `shallowequal`, e.g.
> 
> `import shallowequal from 'shallowequal`
> `import eq from 'shallowequal'`
> 
> If you export the type on top level, you break this, because you have to use
> 
> `import { shallowEqual } from 'shallowequal'`
> 
> or
> 
> `import { shallowEqual, Comparer } from 'shallowequal'`
> 
> So I think it's a good tradeoff to have a namespace which might not be necessary instead of breaking existing codebases.

@seansfkelley Actually, the way @arndissler implemented it is the only valid solution. You can't use a default export here because of what is described [here](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped#a-package-uses-export--but-i-prefer-to-use-default-imports-can-i-change-export--to-export-default). And you can't have multiple `export` statements in a `d.ts` file that has a `export = ...` export.

Ah, thanks for the clarification. Default exports/CommonJS exports/namespace merging always get jumbled up in my head.

FWIW, I think that

> it's kinda more idiomatic to not return anything instead of an `undefined` value

is true; if there is no type safety to be gained by changing from `void` to `undefined` then it's probably best left as `void`.

If you, like me, are the kind of person who doesn't like that idiom, you can always turn on `noImplicitReturns` to make sure you don't let control fall off the end of the function.

I totally agree that it's comfortable to not explicitly write a `return undefined`. 

According to how it is implemented in `shallowequal`, the only valid return values for the `customizer` function are `true`, `false`, `undefined`. If you **don't** enable `strictNullChecks` then the return types are `true`, `false`, `null` and `undefined`, which matches to `void`. My assumption was, that TypeScript's `strictNullCheck` will remove the nullable option from `boolean`, so I wrote `boolean | undefined` to avoid the nullability of `void`. 

My mistake was that I didn't expect TypeScript to remove `null` from `void` when using `strictNullChecks`. So I'll go with changing it back to `void`. Thanks for the discussion ðŸ‘ 

Since I will make some changes to this PR, should I change the name of the parameter `compare` and it's type `Comparer` to `customizer` and `Customizer`, so it matches with shallowequals documentation?

> Since I will make some changes to this PR, should I change the name of the parameter `compare` and it's type `Comparer` to `customizer` and `Customizer`, so it matches with shallowequals documentation?

Sounds reasonable to me.

> My mistake was that I didn't expect TypeScript to remove `null` from `void` when using `strictNullChecks`. So I'll go with changing it back to `void`. Thanks for the discussion ðŸ‘

Thank you for being patient with me being pedantic.
